oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Peer Review as Collective Care: Building a Caring and Critical Editorial Culture at JAAWGE
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Young, Jemimah
Bango, Eboni
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Peer review
collective care
Black feminist
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: The present editorial advances a Black feminist vision of peer review as collective care within the Journal of African American Women and Girls in Education (JAAWGE). Rejecting gatekeeping models that reproduce anti-Blackness and sexism, I conceptualize reviewing as an ethic of love, rigor, and solidarity that safeguards the intellectual and emotional labor of scholars writing about Black women and girls. I describe the structural conditions that overburden Black women with invisible service and argue that equitable review cultures must be intentionally built, not assumed. The editorial outlines care-centered, equity-focused practices for reviewers attending to tone, justice-oriented rigor, race and power, timeliness, and mentoring, as well as issues parallel calls to authors and institutions. I invite authors to receive critique as a protected space for growth and to “pay it forward” through their own reviewing. Finally, I urge institutions to recognize and resource reviewing as essential labor in sustaining liberatory scholarship. Collectively, they sustain a just home.
